work.p: These draft lines are similar to lines that appear in a long manuscript poem unpublished in Whitman's lifetime, titled "Pictures." The first several lines of "Pictures" were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310).

titleStmt.title: See there is Epicurus
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript and another to which it was originally joined ("Poem of Pictures"; uva.00289) are likely related to "Pictures," a long manuscript poem held at the Beinecke Library at Yale University that was probably written in the mid- to late-1850s. uva.00289 is also probably related to "Poem of Salutation," first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass and later retitled "Salut au Monde!" Therefore, the date of this manuscript is probably before 1856. Whitman used lines from "Pictures" for the poem "My Picture-Gallery," first published in Leaves of Grass (1881–1882).

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: [See there is Epicurus]
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Collection, 1842–1957, Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
This manuscript was originally continuous with the manuscript "Poem of Pictures" (uva.00289), from which it was later cut, presumably by Whitman.

revisionDesc.change: revised date and date note to accord with other manuscripts related to "Pictures," especially uva.00289; added relatedItem note to connect this with uva.00289

lg.l:
I see,
Behold See there in is in Athens, Epicurus—see the old philosoph
in his a gr porch teaching

His physique is perfect ? full
—his voice
is clear and mu sonorous—
his white hair the s his phre‑phrenology
nology perfect,

He calls around him, his school of
young men—he gathers them
in the street, or conducts saunters
with them along the banks of
the river, arguing,
